entities.name: Affordances
entities.description: The perceived and actual properties of an object that determine how it could possibly be used. Originally from James Gibson, Norman popularized it in design.

entities.name: Signifiers
entities.description: Signals that communicate where and how an action should take place. Norman introduced this term to clarify affordances.

entities.name: Constraints
entities.description: Physical, cultural, semantic, and logical limitations that guide user behavior and prevent errors.

entities.name: Mapping
entities.description: The relationship between controls and their effects. Natural mappings follow physical, cultural, or semantic principles.

entities.name: Feedback
entities.description: Communication about the results of an action. Must be immediate, informative, and appropriate.

entities.name: Conceptual Model
entities.description: A simplified explanation of how something works, held by both designers and users.

entities.name: Mental Model
entities.description: The user's internal representation of how a system works, which may differ from the designer's model.

entities.name: Gulf of Execution
entities.description: The gap between a user's intention and the physical actions allowed by the system.

entities.name: Gulf of Evaluation
entities.description: The gap between the system's state and the user's perception of that state.

entities.name: Visceral Design
entities.description: The initial, automatic emotional response to appearance - the 'gut reaction' to a product's look and feel.

entities.name: Behavioral Design
entities.description: The level of design concerned with use and experience - how well does the product work?

entities.name: Reflective Design
entities.description: The level of design about message, culture, and meaning - what does using this product say about me?

entities.name: Norman Door
entities.description: A door whose design makes it unclear whether to push or pull. Term coined by others based on Norman's work.

entities.name: Human-Centered Design (HCD)
entities.description: Design approach that starts with understanding people, their needs, and their contexts.

entities.name: User Experience (UX)
entities.description: Term coined by Norman at Apple to encompass all aspects of the user's interaction with a company and its products.

entities.name: Design Thinking
entities.description: Creative problem-solving methodology: empathize, define, ideate, prototype, test.

entities.name: Humanity-Centered Design
entities.description: Evolution of HCD that considers broader societal and environmental impacts, not just individual users.

entities.name: DesignX
entities.description: Initiative focused on design for complex sociotechnical systems.

entities.name: Discoverability
entities.description: The ability to determine what actions are possible and the current state of a device.

entities.name: Root Cause Analysis
entities.description: Systematic investigation of why errors occur, looking at system design rather than human blame.

entities.name: Jakob Nielsen
entities.description: Usability pioneer, co-founder of Nielsen Norman Group with Don Norman.

entities.name: James J. Gibson
entities.description: Psychologist who originated the concept of affordances that Norman later adapted for design.

entities.name: Steve Jobs
entities.description: Apple co-founder; Norman worked under his leadership as VP.

entities.name: Stephen Draper
entities.description: Co-editor of 'User Centered System Design' with Norman.

entities.name: Alan Kay
entities.description: Computer scientist at Apple's ATG; colleague of Norman.

entities.name: The Design of Everyday Things
entities.description: Norman's most influential book, originally titled 'The Psychology of Everyday Things' (1988, revised 2013).

entities.name: Emotional Design
entities.description: 2004 book introducing visceral/behavioral/reflective framework.

entities.name: Living with Complexity
entities.description: 2010 book arguing complexity isn't the enemy, bad design is.

entities.name: The Invisible Computer
entities.description: 1998 book arguing technology should become invisible through design.

entities.name: The Design of Future Things
entities.description: 2007 book on designing for autonomous and intelligent machines.

entities.name: Nielsen Norman Group
entities.description: UX consulting firm co-founded by Norman and Nielsen in 1998.

entities.name: Apple Computer
entities.description: Company where Norman served as VP of Advanced Technology Group (1993-1998).

entities.name: UC San Diego
entities.description: University where Norman spent most of his academic career and is Professor Emeritus.

entities.name: UCSD Design Lab
entities.description: Design research lab at UC San Diego where Norman serves as Director.

entities.name: MIT
entities.description: Where Norman received his B.S. in Electrical Engineering.

entities.name: University of Pennsylvania
entities.description: Where Norman received his M.S. and Ph.D.

entities.name: IDEO
entities.description: Design firm that has worked closely with Norman's principles.

entities.name: Three Mile Island
entities.description: Nuclear power plant whose 1979 accident was a turning point in Norman's career.

entities.name: jnd.org
entities.description: Norman's personal website with essays and design insights.

entities.name: ACM CHI
entities.description: Premier international conference on Human-Computer Interaction.

entities.name: IxDA
entities.description: Interaction Design Association, which created the Don Norman Design Award.

entities.name: Cognitive Science
entities.description: Interdisciplinary study of mind and intelligence that Norman helped establish.

entities.name: Human Error
entities.description: Term Norman argues is a misnomer - should be called 'system error' or 'design error'.

entities.name: Usability
entities.description: The ease with which a product can be used - central but not sufficient for good design.

entities.name: Slip
entities.description: Error that occurs when the action performed is not what was intended (automatic behavior).

entities.name: Mistake
entities.description: Error that occurs when the goal or plan is wrong (conscious behavior).

entities.name: Forcing Function
entities.description: Design element that prevents incorrect behavior or forces correct sequence.

entities.name: Knowledge in the World vs Head
entities.description: Distinction between information stored externally (affordances, signifiers) vs internally (memory).

entities.name: Seven Stages of Action
entities.description: Goal, Plan, Specify, Perform, Perceive, Interpret, Compare - model of human action.

entities.name: Double Diamond
entities.description: Design process model: Discover, Define, Develop, Deliver.

entities.name: Activity-Centered Design
entities.description: Design approach focused on activities and tasks rather than technology.

entities.name: TED
entities.description: Platform where Norman delivered influential talk on emotional design.

entities.name: Benjamin Franklin Medal
entities.description: Prestigious award Norman received in Computer and Cognitive Science (2011).

entities.name: SIGCHI Lifetime Research Award
entities.description: ACM CHI's highest recognition for lifetime contribution to HCI (2017).

entities.name: Don Norman Design Award
entities.description: IxDA award named after Norman for design addressing societal challenges.

entities.name: Natural Mapping
entities.description: When control arrangement matches physical arrangement of what's being controlled.

entities.name: Poka-Yoke
entities.description: Japanese term for error-proofing; related to Norman's design principles.

entities.name: Learned Helplessness
entities.description: Psychological state where people believe they can't succeed, often caused by bad design.

entities.name: Feature Creep
entities.description: The gradual addition of features that makes products harder to use.

entities.name: Satisficing
entities.description: Choosing a 'good enough' option rather than optimal; how users actually behave.

entities.name: Design Thinking Process
entities.description: Iterate: Observe, Generate Ideas, Prototype, Test, Repeat.

entities.name: Sociotechnical Systems
entities.description: Complex systems involving both technical components and human/social elements.

entities.name: High Resolution Podcast
entities.description: Podcast featuring in-depth interview with Norman.

entities.name: 99% Invisible
entities.description: Design podcast that popularized the term 'Norman Door'.

entities.name: User Research
entities.description: Systematic study of users and their requirements, foundational to HCD.

entities.name: Iterative Design
entities.description: Cyclic process of prototyping, testing, analyzing, and refining.

entities.name: Ethnographic Research
entities.description: Observational research method to understand users in context.

entities.name: Persona
entities.description: Fictional representation of a user type, used in user-centered design.

entities.name: Scenario-Based Design
entities.description: Design method using narrative descriptions of user interactions.

entities.name: System Image
entities.description: What the system presents to the user - should match designer's conceptual model.

entities.name: Cognitive Load
entities.description: The mental effort required to process information; design should minimize it.

entities.name: Heuristic Evaluation
entities.description: Usability inspection method using heuristics; related to Norman's principles.

entities.name: Dark Patterns
entities.description: Manipulative design practices that Norman criticizes.

entities.name: Design Ethics
entities.description: Moral principles that should guide design decisions.

entities.name: Sustainable Design
entities.description: Design that considers environmental impact; part of humanity-centered design.

entities.name: Inclusive Design
entities.description: Design that works for people of all abilities.

entities.name: Universal Design
entities.description: Design usable by all people without need for adaptation.

entities.name: Wicked Problems
entities.description: Complex problems with no clear solution; addressed by DesignX.

entities.name: Artificial Intelligence (AI)
entities.description: Technology Norman increasingly discusses regarding design implications.

entities.name: Automation
entities.description: Topic Norman has written about extensively, especially human-automation interaction.

entities.name: User-Centered System Design
entities.description: 1986 book co-edited with Stephen Draper, foundational HCI text.

entities.name: Turn Signals Are the Facial Expressions of Automobiles
entities.description: 1992 collection of essays on design.

entities.name: Institute for Cognitive Science (UCSD)
entities.description: Research institute Norman founded at UC San Diego in 1977.

entities.name: Design for a Better World
entities.description: Upcoming book Norman is working on about humanity-centered design.

entities.name: Fast Company
entities.description: Magazine where Norman has published design articles.
